info.title: Akahu REST API
info.description: This API is the primary way for apps to interact with a user's data.

user_token.description:
User-level Authentication:

Http Bearer Auth with the token being a consented **User Access Token**.
> `Bearer {user_token}`

This will allow you to act on a **user's** behalf when accessing the API.

app_auth.description:
App-level Authentication:

HTTP Basic Auth with the username being your **App ID Token** and the password being your **App Secret**.
> `Basic {app_token}:{app_secret}`

This will allow you to act as your Akahu **application**, rather than as a specific user.

401.description: You are not authorised to access this content.

403.description: You are not allowed to access this content.

404.description: The item you are trying to access doesn't exist.

429.description: You have been rate limited on this endpoint.

500.description: An internal error has prevented us from processing the request. More detail may be supplied in the `message` key.

_id.description: A unique identifier for the account in the Akahu system. It is always be prefixed by `acc_` so that you can tell that it belongs to an account.

_credentials.description: When you connect accounts to Akahu you have to log in. Akahu keeps track of all of the accounts in that login session and gives them all a unique `_credentials` key, prefixed by `creds_`.

connection.description: Information about the financial institution where the account is held (eg. ANZ bank).

_id.description: A unique identifier for this institution, prefixed by `conn_`.

logo.description: A URL pointing to an image of the institution's logo.

name.description: The name of this account. If the connection allows customisation, the name will be the custom name (or nickname), eg. "Spending Account". Otherwise Akahu falls back to the product name, eg. "Super Saver".

status.description:
This attribute indicates the status of Akahu's connection to this account.

It is possible for Akahu to lose the ability to authenticate with a financial institution if the user revokes Akahu's access directly via their institution, or changes their login credentials, which in some cases can cause our long-lived access to be revoked.

The account `status` will be one of:

- `ACTIVE` Akahu can authenticate with the institution to retrieve data and/or initiate payments for this account.

- `INACTIVE` Akahu no longer has access to this account. Your application will still be able to access Akahu's cached copy of data for this account, but this will no longer be updated by [refreshes](/docs/data-refreshes). Write actions such as payments or transfers will no longer be available. Once an account is assigned the `INACTIVE` status, it will stay this way until the user re-establishes the connection. When your application observes an account with a status of `INACTIVE`, the user should be directed back to the Akahu OAuth flow or to https://my.akahu.nz/connections where they will be prompted to re-establish the connection.

currency.description: The (3 letter ISO 4217 currency code)[https://www.xe.com/iso4217.php] that this balance is in.

available.description: The balance that is currently available to the account holder.

limit.description: The credit limit for this account. For example a credit card limit or an overdraft limit. This value is only present when provided directly by the connected financial institution.

overdrawn.description: A boolean indicating whether this account is in unarranged overdraft.

type.description:
Type of account, Akahu provides specific bank account types, and falls back to more general types for other types of connection.
- `CHECKING` → An everyday spending account.
- `SAVINGS` → A savings account.
- `CREDITCARD` → A credit card.
- `LOAN` → A loan account.
- `KIWISAVER` → A KiwiSaver investment product.
- `INVESTMENT` → A general investment product.
- `TERMDEPOSIT` → A term deposit.
- `FOREIGN` → An account holding a foreign currency.
- `TAX` → An account with tax authorities.
- `REWARDS` → An account for rewards points, e.g. Fly Buys or True Rewards.
- `WALLET` → Available cash for investment or withdrawal from an investment provider.

attributes.description:
The list of attributes indicates which abilities an account has. A list of:
- `TRANSACTIONS` → account has transactions and supports retrieval of these via Akahu.
- `TRANSFER_TO` → account can receive transfers from other accounts belonging to same set of credentials.
- `TRANSFER_FROM` → account can initiate transfers to other accounts belonging to the same set of credentials.
- `PAYMENT_TO` → account can receive payments from any Akahu account with the `PAYMENT_FROM` attribute.
- `PAYMENT_FROM` → account can initiate payments to any Akahu account with the `PAYMENT_TO` attribute.

formatted_account.description: If the account has a well defined account number (eg. a bank account number, or credit card number) this will be defined here with a standard format across connections. Credit cards will have at least 8 digits redacted.

holder.example: MR DEMO HOLDER & MS DEMO HOLDER

loan_details.description: Details about a loan account, if available.

purpose.description: The purpose of the loan, if we can't determine the purpose, this will be `UNKNOWN`

type.description: The type of loan, if we can't determine the type, this will be `UNKNOWN`

interest.description: Interest rate information for the loan.

rate.description: The interest rate on the loan.

expires_at.description: When this interest rate expires, if available.

is_interest_only.description: Is the loan currently in an interest only period?

years.description: The number of years the loan is for.

months.description: The number of months the loan is for.

matures_at.description: When the loan matures, if available.

initial_principal.description: The loan initial principal amount, this was the original amount borrowed.

frequency.description: The frequency of the loan repayment.

next_date.description: The next repayment date, if available.

refreshed.description: Akahu can refresh different parts of an account's data at different rates. The timestamps in the `refreshed` object tell you when that account data was last updated. This can be thought of as "Akahu's view of the account (balance/metadata/transactions) is up to date as of \$TIME".

party.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp when we last fetched identity data about the party who has authenticated with the financial institution when connecting this account.

AddressType.description:
Type of address:

- `RESIDENTIAL` → Where the user lives.

- `POSTAL` → Where the user can be reached by mail such as a PO-BOX.

- `UNKNOWN` → Akahu was unable to determine which of the two types of address this is.

Addresses.description: Address derived from a user's connected accounts.

formatted_address.description: Optional parsed and formatted address string.
formatted_address.example: 27 Bag End, Bagshot Row, Hobbiton, Middle Earth, 1011

components.description: Breakdown of the parts that make up this address.

status.description:
- `PROCESSING` → Identity request is in progress, continue to poll for a final state of `COMPLETE` or `ERROR`.

- `COMPLETE` → Final success status reached and identity data has been returned.

- `ERROR` → Final error status reached due to a fatal error occurred during processing.

For more details about one of identity statuses see:
  - [📖 Identity Status reference](/docs/the-oneoff-identity-result-model#identity-status)

_id.description: A unique identifier for this income source. It is always prefixed by income_.

_account.description: The Akahu Account ID that this income source belongs to.

start.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp of the start date for this income query.

end.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp of the end date for this income query.

name.description: The clean name for this income source

type.description:
Income type:

- `SALARY` → Money earnt from a job salary payment

- `BENEFIT` → Money received from govt benefit program

- `RENT` → Money coming in for a rental i.e renting a property

- `INTEREST` → Money earnt from accruing interest on an investment

- `OFFSHORE` → Money received from an overseas account

- `DEPOSIT` → Money received to reserve or use a certain goods or services

frequency.description:
The frequency of income payments:

  - `WEEKLY` → Active and recurring income on a weekly basis.

  - `BIWEEKLY`→ Active and recurring income every two weeks or on a twice week basis.

  - `MONTHLY` → Active and recurring income on a monthly basis.

  - `INACTIVE` → Income failed meet the criteria of an current ongoing recurring pattern, for example this may be income for a past job.

  - `IRREGULAR`→ Payments do not follow a recurring pattern.

stability.description: An indication of the stability of this income source. This object is only included if the income frequency is recurring and is active (frequency is WEEKLY, BIWEEKLY or MONTHLY).

payment_regularity.description: Standard deviation of the difference in days between payments. The closer this is to 0, the more regular the payments are. Less than 1 is a good indication that this income is being paid regularly.

payment_amount.description: Standard deviation of the difference in amounts between payments. The closer this is to 0 this is means the more consistent the payment amounts are. Less than 1 is a good indication that the payment amounts are consistent.

projections.description: Projections for this income source. This object is only included if the income frequency is recurring and is active (frequency is WEEKLY, BIWEEKLY or MONTHLY).

yearly_net_income.description: Projected yearly net income for this income source.

pay_day.description: Projected day of the week that income is received.

next_date.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp of the next day income will be received.

next_payment_amount.description: Projected amount of the next payment.

items.description: Lower and upper bound of an estimated gross amount for this income if it was subject to usual Salary deductions. This is a fairly wide range since it takes into account all possible values for deductions such as PAYE, ACC and Kiwisaver.

max.description: The max value of all the credits assigned to this income source.

mean.description: The average value of all the credits assigned to this income source.

median.description: The median value of all the credits assigned to this income source.

min.description: The minimum value of all the credits assigned to this income source.

total.description: The summed value of all the credits assigned to this income source.

mode.description: The mode value of all the credits assigned to this income source.

count.description: The number of credit transactions for this income source in this period

first.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp of when the first credit transaction in this income source transaction was created by the bank

last.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp of when the last credit transaction in this income source transaction was created by the bank

items.description: A simplified transaction model used to show the transactions within this income source. This property is only visible if you have the TRANSACTIONS permission. To get the full transaction object use the Transactions API.

amount.description: How much money this transaction was for

date.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp of when this transaction was created by the bank

description.description: The raw transaction description, essentially what you see on a bank statement

TransactionType.description:
Type of the transaction:

  - `CREDIT` → Money has entered the account.

  - `DEBIT` → Money has left the account.

  - `PAYMENT` → Payment to an external account.

  - `TRANSFER` → Transfer between accounts that are associated with the same credentials.

  - `STANDING ORDER` → Automatic payment.

  - `EFTPOS` → Payment made via an EFTPOS system.

  - `INTEREST` → An interest payment.

  - `FEE` → Fee payment to the account provider.

  - `TAX` → Tax payment.

  - `CREDIT CARD` → Credit card payment.

  - `DIRECT DEBIT` → Direct debit payment.

  - `DIRECT CREDIT` → Direct credit (someone paying into the account).

  - `ATM` → ATM deposit or withdrawal.

  - `LOAN` → Loan payment.

status.description:
Status of the payment:
- `READY` → Initial state payment is ready to be processed.

- `PENDING_APPROVAL` → Payment requires user approval before processing see the guide for more details.

- `SENT` → Payment initiated with the user's bank and we've received confirmation that it has been accepted.

- `PAUSED` → Payment is not yet ready to be processed.

- `DECLINED` → Payment has been declined by the user's bank.

- `CANCELLED` → Payment was cancelled.

- `ERROR` → Internal Akahu error occurred.

For more details see:
  - [📚 Payments guide](/docs/making-a-payment)
  - [📚 Payments lifecycle guide](/docs/making-a-payment#payment-lifecycle)

status.description:
Transfer status:

- `READY` → Transfer is ready to be processed.

- `PENDING_APPROVAL` → Transfer requires user approval before processing see the guide for more details.

- `SENT` → Transfer has been processed and has appeared in the transactions of the source account.

- `PAUSED` → Transfer is not yet ready to be processed.

- `DECLINED` → The transfer has been declined by the source bank.

- `ERROR` → Internal Akahu error occurred.

For more details see:
  - [📚 Transfer guide](/docs/making-a-transfer).
  - [📚 Transfer lifecycle guide](/docs/making-a-transfer#transfer-lifecycle)

tags.name: Data Refresh
tags.description: These endpoints allow you to request for Akahu to begin pulling in data from the original source (e.g. a bank). Refreshing is **rate limited**. A new refresh will begin only after 5 minutes has passed since the last refresh.

tags.name: Support
tags.description:
(Beta) Akahu provides an API based support system, allowing you to return feedback and point out issues from within your application.

You must specify a specific `_id` in the url to notify us about, and then specify your request payload depending on the type of message you wish to send us.

Revoke your application's access to one of the user's connected accounts and its associated data, including transactions.

Use this if you no longer require access to the consented account data.

> ℹ️

For more details see:

post.summary: Exchange an Authorization Code For a Token
post.description:
This endpoint is the final step in our [📖 OAuth Authentication Flow](/docs/authorizing-with-oauth2).

Use this endpoint to exchange an **Authorization Code** for a **User Access Token**, which can be used to access the rest of this API.

> ℹ️ Endpoint not applicable for `Personal Apps`
>
> See our [📚 Getting started guide](/docs/getting-started) to set up your Personal App.

To ensure that your application does not retain unnecessary access to user data, [revoke](./delete_token) this access token in the event that is no longer required (e.g. the user deletes their account).

> 📘 OAuth2 Error Responses
>
> In keeping with the OAuth2 specification, error responses from this endpoint contain an error in the `error` field, rather than the `message` field used by other Akahu endpoints.

For more details see:
- [📚 OAuth Authentication Flow](/docs/authorizing-with-oauth2).
- [📖 Auth scopes](/docs/scopes)
- [📖 Token webhooks](/docs/reference-webhooks#token)
- [📚 Accessing transactional data guide](/docs/accessing-transactional-data)
- [📚 Accessing account data guide](/docs/accessing-account-data)

code.description: The code to be exchanged for a **User Access Token**, received upon the user's completion of the authorization redirect flow.

redirect_uri.description: Same `redirect_uri` you specified to start the OAuth flow to receive an exchange code.

400.description: Your request was malformed or otherwise unacceptable. The `error` key in the response will be on one of the standard OAuth error codes.

invalid_grant.description: There is something wrong with this OAuth request. Ensure you're following the specification.

invalid Request.description: This request is invalid. Ensure you're following the specification.

unsupported_grant_type.description: The grant type must always be `authorization_code`

delete.description:
Revokes the **User Access Token** that is included in the `Authorization` header of the request.

Revoking a User Access Token will remove your access to **all** of a user's connected account data including transactions.

> ℹ️
>
> Users can re-authorize your application's access to their accounts via the [📚 authorization flow](/docs/authorizing-with-oauth2).

post.description:
This endpoint requests a data refresh for all accounts that the user has connected to your application.

Account data such as balance and transactions are periodically refreshed by Akahu and enriched **asynchronously**, providing clean and consistent data across financial institutions.

However, there may be certain times that your app requires the most up-to-date account data possible, this endpoint allows you to request a refresh on-demand for these cases.

For more details see:
- [📚 Data Refreshes guide](/docs/data-refreshes)

429.description: You have been rate limited on this endpoint.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: An Akahu Account or Connection ID

post.description:
This endpoint requests a data refresh for a specific financial institution or a specific account that the user has connected to your application.

#### Connection ID

Calling this endpoint with a **Connection** ID will request that Akahu performs a data refresh for all of the user's connected accounts that are held at the financial institution corresponding to that Connection.

#### Account ID

Calling this endpoint with an **Account** ID will request that Akahu performs a data refresh for that specific connected account and any other connected accounts that are associated with the same login credentials.

For example, if the user has shared three ASB accounts from a single set of login credentials and you request a refresh for one, the other two accounts will also be refreshed.

For more details see:

Gets a list of the user's transactions that match the provided list of Akahu transaction identifiers.

The intended use for this endpoint is to assist in [📖 transaction webhooks](/docs/reference-webhooks#transaction).
When a webhook arrives it contains a list of changed transaction identifiers, which you can simply pass unchanged to this endpoint to retrieve the full transactions.

This endpoint is unusual, in that it is really a `GET`, dressed up as a `POST`.
The reason we do this is to avoid having to put all of the IDs in query parameters, which could potentially come up against maximum URL length constraints.

- Transactions will look different depending on your app's permissions.
- All times on the transaction are in **UTC**.

For more details see:
- [📚 Accessing transactional data guide](/docs/accessing-transactional-data)
- [📖 Transaction model](/docs/the-transaction-model)

post.description:
Let us know when we get something wrong 🙏.
The request body should match the type of request you are making:

### Notify Us Of A Duplicate ###

| Parameter  | Example                             | Description                                                                            |
|:-----------|:------------------------------------|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `type`     | `"DUPLICATE"`                       | Let us know that two Akahu transactions are actually the same transaction in the bank. |
| `other_id` | `"trans_1111111111111111111111111"` | The duplicate transaction ID.                                                          |

### Notify Us Of An Enrichment Error ###

| Parameter  | Example                              | Description                                           |
|:-----------|:-------------------------------------|:------------------------------------------------------|
| `type`     | `"ENRICHMENT_ERROR"`                 | Let us know when we get something wrong.              |
| `fields`   | `[ "merchant.name"]`                 | A list of dot-separated paths to the incorrect values |
| `comment`  | `"X should be Y"`                    | Additional info you want to include.                  |

### Suggest An Improvement To Enrichment Data ###

| Parameter  | Example                        | Description                                                                                           |
|:-----------|:-------------------------------|:------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `type`     | `"ENRICHMENT_SUGGESTION"`      | Let us know about further enrichment that can be applied to this transaction transaction in the bank. |
| `comment`  | `"Can you please add X to Y?"` | The enrichment information you want to tell us about.                                                 |

type.description:
What type of support request you want to make:

- `DUPLICATE` → Report duplicate transactions.

- `ENRICHMENT_ERROR` → Enrichment is incorrect or contained unexpected data.

- `ENRICHMENT_SUGGESTION` → Suggest an improvement on existing enrichment.

other_id.description: In the case of duplicates, the duplicate transaction ID.

fields.description: In the case of enrichment errors, the dot-separated paths to the incorrect values.

comment.description: A comment describing the problem and giving extra details.
